stem: A patient cannot form a normal 'OK' sign; the thumb IP and index DIP fail to flex. Which lesion best explains this finding?

choices.A: Pronator syndrome (median nerve at pronator teres)
choices.B: Anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve lesion

rationale_correct: AIN supplies FPL and the lateral half of FDP; weakness prevents thumb IP and index DIP flexion when making the 'OK' sign.

rationale_distractors.A: Pronator syndrome typically presents with sensory symptoms; FPL/FDP function is often preserved.
rationale_distractors.C: Ulnar canal syndrome affects digit 5 and medial 4; not the 'OK' sign pattern.
rationale_distractors.D: PIN palsy affects finger/wrist extensors (posterior compartment), not FPL/FDP.
rationale_distractors.E: Axillary nerve deficits involve deltoid/teres minor and shoulder abduction.

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb Lecture Notes. Sep 22, 2025.
